item.title: Kai Cenat is Getting His Own Fortnite Skin
item.description:
Kai Cenat has confirmed that he will be the next content creator to receive a Fortnite skin as part of the game's Icon Series, celebrating streamers and celebrities alike. The massively popular battle royale from Epic Games has welcomed a wide variety of different skins into the game, expanding from its own characters into a variety of crossovers. Fortnite has featured everything from TV shows and movies to popular musicians like Mariah Carey and Eminem as in-game skins for players to acquire. Now, one of the internet's most popular streamers will be making his Fortnite debut.

Fortnite 's "Icon Series" skins serve as an homage to popular celebrities and some of the game's most well-known streamers. The Icon Series has featured the addition of multiple popular musicians as in-game skins, with Travis Scott and Major Lazer serving as some of the earliest musicians added to the game. The skin line has also been the home to skins for several of Fortnite 's most beloved content creators, with streamers like Ninja, TheGrefg, and Lachlan receiving their own in-game cosmetics. Kai Cenat has now confirmed he will be the next online star to join Fortnite 's Icon Series.

As reported by Dexerto, Kai Cenat officially dropped the news about his upcoming Fortnite appearance on his Twitter account. The streamer revealed that he would be hosting a stream on August 18 to reveal the details about his upcoming appearance in Fortnite as a part of the "Icon Series" line of skins. Kai Cenat's announcement about the Fortnite skin appears to have even caught Epic Games off -guard, jokingly responding "LEAKED" while simultaneously seemingly confirming the skin's existence. Kai Cenat did not reveal any information about a release date for his Fortnite skin in the post.

Kai Cenat Reveals New Icon Series Fortnite Skin

The introduction of a Kai Cenat skin to Fortnite comes as the streamer has consistently maintained his status as one of Twitch's most popular talents. Kai Cenat regularly sits within the top 5 most-subscribed channels on Twitch, currently boasting the third-highest follower count on the platform. Kai Cenat's overwhelming success on Twitch has seen the streamer expand his brand beyond video gaming, even hosting a livestream from the 2025 Grammy Awards ceremony.

Fortnite 's newest content creator skin comes as the game has plenty more exciting crossovers rumored to be on the way soon. Recent leaks have suggested that this year's "Fortnitemares" Halloween event may include brand-new Scooby-Doo Fortnite skins, including multiple variants of Shaggy. Rumors have also hinted at new skins based on Friday the 13th coming as part of the event, with Jason Voorhees teased as a major Halloween skin for this year. Kai Cenat's debut as a Fortnite skin should be a major event for the beloved streamer's legions of passionate fans.

item.title: Best Dystopian Games
item.description:
Summary

  • Dystopian games should immerse players in broken, functioning worlds.
  • Grim visions in games like Mad Max, Kenshi, and BioShock evoke plausible horrors.
  • From oppressive surveillance to ruthless control, these games force players to live in bleak realities.

Not every post-apocalyptic game is truly dystopian . Dystopia is a specific flavor of nightmare, one that thrives on surveillance, corruption, social decay, and the quiet (or not-so-quiet) horror of systems built to grind people down. The best dystopian games don’t just show a world in ruins; they show a world still functioning, just barely, in all the worst possible ways.

From crumbling futures and authoritarian regimes to bureaucratic nightmares and failed utopias, these games paint grim visions that feel just plausible enough to stick in the brain long after the credits roll. Here are some of the best examples of games that didn’t just imagine a broken world, but forced players to live in it.

Mad Max

Gasoline, Sandstorms, And The Loneliness Of The Open Wastes

Mad Max
7 /10
11
8.5 /10
Released
September 1, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language, Use of Drugs
Developer(s)
Avalanche Studios
Powered by

Mad Max drops players into a version of Australia that looks like the world ended in fire and then kept baking under a cruel sun. The open world is massive and bleak, filled with convoys, outposts, and half-dead scavengers clinging to whatever scraps they can tear off the bones of civilization. There’s no law, no trust, and definitely no sympathy. Just survival, V8 engines, and an occasional thunderstorm of fire.

However, it’s not just a playground for vehicular chaos. It’s a world that never lets players forget what was lost. The scarcity of water and fuel isn’t just a mechanic; it’s a worldview. Every camp is a reminder of human desperation, with cages full of prisoners and makeshift altars built to worship combustion. Even Max himself, wandering through the wasteland in search of peace, feels like a relic trying to matter in a world that forgot how to care.

Kenshi

Freedom Costs Everything, Including Your Legs

Kenshi
10.0 /10
Released
December 6, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
nr
Developer(s)
Lo-Fi Games
Powered by

There’s no tutorial in Kenshi . No guiding hand, just an empty desert, a dozen factions that hate each other, and the freedom to make the worst decisions imaginable. It’s not post-apocalyptic in the traditional sense, but the world has clearly collapsed under the weight of something ancient, and now it's limping along on rusted robotics and slavery-fueled city-states.

Players who survive long enough to build a home will probably do it on a pile of their own corpses. The world is indifferent to effort and actively punishes weakness. Entire limbs can be hacked off in battle and replaced with mechanical ones, if players can afford them. While the sandbox offers endless choice, most paths lead to war, starvation, or subjugation. That’s the charm. In Kenshi , the dystopia isn't a backdrop. It’s the core mechanic.

Mirror's Edge

When Even Running Is An Act Of Rebellion

Mirror's Edge
7.1 /10
Released
November 11, 2008

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Blood, Language, Violence
Developer(s)
DICE
Powered by

Glass towers, sterile hallways, and a city obsessed with control— Mirror’s Edge doesn’t look dystopian at first glance, but beneath the gleaming skyline lies a world where information is censored, movement is monitored, and silence is enforced with bullets. Players take on the role of Faith, a Runner who uses parkour to move secrets through the city without getting caught.

What makes the setting unsettling is how clean everything looks. There are no smoking ruins or starving masses. Just a quiet, suffocating calm. Cameras watch every corner, doors lock on command, and the only resistance comes from those willing to leap across rooftops for a sliver of freedom. The combat isn’t the focus; escaping is. Because in this world, running is the last thing that isn’t controlled.

Inside

There’s A Reason No One In This World Smiles

Inside
9 /10
8.4 /10
Released
June 29, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Violence
Developer(s)
Playdead
Powered by

Inside never explains itself. It just starts. A small boy running through a gray forest, chased by men with flashlights, tranquilizers, and something worse. From that first screen, everything feels wrong. Not loud, explosive wrong; subtle, gnawing wrong. The world is grim and quiet, filled with mind-control machines, zombie-like workers, and glimpses of experiments that should not exist.

The puzzles feel like the only control players have in a world that’s been drained of meaning. There are no spoken words. Just mechanical clanks, muffled screams, and the distant hum of something massive moving under the surface. Even the ending, as strange and unforgettable as it is, refuses to offer closure. Inside doesn’t want players to understand its world. It wants them to feel trapped in it.

Disco Elysium

The Real Dystopia Is In The Mirror

Disco Elysium
9 /10
12
9.6 /10
Released
October 15, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood, Sexual Themes, Strong Language, Use of Drugs, Violence
Developer(s)
ZA/UM
Powered by

Revachol is a city so broken that it’s barely standing. Communism failed, capitalism abandoned it, and what’s left is a slurry of forgotten ideologies, war trauma, and bureaucratic despair. Disco Elysium isn’t about fixing anything; it’s about understanding why everything feels unfixable. Even the detective who players control isn’t immune to it; he's a product of it. An amnesiac, drug-fueled shell of a man trying to solve a murder in a city that’s already dead inside.

There are no shootouts or car chases here. Just endless dialogue, internal monologues, and choices that pull the player deeper into a web of philosophy, self-loathing, and unexpected beauty. The real dystopia is personal. It’s the system in the character’s own head, the city that reflects his every failing, and the knowledge that some things are broken long before the story begins.

BioShock

Would You Kindly Admit This Is A Nightmare?

BioShock
15
9.5 /10
Released
August 21, 2007

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
m
Developer(s)
Irrational Games
Powered by

BioShock doesn’t open with warnings of an apocalypse. It opens with the promise of a utopia—Rapture, a city built at the bottom of the ocean where artists, scientists, and businessmen were supposed to be free from government control. By the time players arrive, though, it's a monument to everything that can go wrong when people are too free.

Rapture is falling apart in every sense. Plasmid-addicted Splicers roam the halls, Big Daddies lumber through flooded corridors, and the walls echo with propaganda that has long outlived its relevance. The real horror isn't just the bodies on the floor. It's the fact that this world was supposed to be better. The water seeping through the cracks isn’t just a visual; it’s a symbol of ideals collapsing under their own weight.

We Happy Few

Smile For The Camera, Or Else

We Happy Few
7.0 /10
Released
August 10, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood, Strong Language, Suggestive Themes, Use of Drugs and Alcohol, Violence
Developer(s)
Compulsion Games
Powered by

Set in an alternate 1960s England where a national trauma has been papered over with mandatory happy pills, We Happy Few presents a society where denial is law and emotions are treason. Anyone not smiling wide enough is labeled a "Downer" and hunted like a virus. The city is bright, colorful, and constantly surveilled, but the cheerfulness is artificial and enforced with violence.

Players alternate between three deeply flawed protagonists, each uncovering a piece of what actually happened in Wellington Wells. The story is fragmented, much like the society it depicts, and the mechanics lean heavily into crafting, stealth, and the constant pressure to blend in or die. It’s less about fighting the system and more about surviving its expectations. And beneath all the confetti and parade masks, there's nothing but rot.

Papers, Please

Glory To Arstotzka, And Also Therapy

Papers, Please
9 /10
7.8 /10
Released
August 8, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Violence, Blood, Sexual Themes, Nudity, Drug Reference, Strong Language
Developer(s)
3909 LLC
Powered by

Papers, Please traps players in a cramped immigration booth with a stack of documents, a rubber stamp, and the crushing weight of moral compromise. As an immigration officer in the fictional communist country of Arstotzka, players must decide who gets to enter and who gets turned away. The catch is that getting it wrong can cost lives, and so can getting it right.

It’s a game about procedure, repetition, and the slow erosion of empathy. The people on the other side of the glass become numbers, unless players let themselves care, which comes with its own risks. The music is bleak, the colors are oppressive, and the world outside the booth is never fully visible, but it doesn’t need to be. The dystopia lives in the paperwork, in the decisions made in a few seconds, and in the creeping sense that there’s no right answer.

Deus Ex

The Future Is Canceled, But Augmented

6 Images
6 Images
Deus Ex
6.7 /10
Released
June 23, 2000

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ // Blood, Violence
Developer(s)
Ion Storm
Powered by

Few games predicted the future quite like Deus Ex . Cybernetic implants, mega-corporations, fake news, digital surveillance; everything that sounded like sci-fi in 2000 feels like a Tuesday now, but what makes this dystopia hit harder is how plausible it all feels. The world is on the brink of collapse, held together by conspiracies and half-truths, and players are thrown into it with too much power and not enough certainty.

Whether they're sneaking through shadowy laboratories, hacking into locked networks, or negotiating with people who may or may not be human anymore, everything feels like it’s happening under someone else’s watch. Every choice, no matter how well-intentioned, seems to feed into a system that’s already made up its mind. Deus Ex doesn’t just let players change the world. It forces them to realize how little that might actually mean.

item.title: How to Complete the Hot Tea Legacy Challenge in The Sims 4
item.description:
The Sims 4 is the fourth, and longest-running, installment of the simulation series, and players have found new and exciting ways to enjoy the game over the years. Cheats, mods, and custom content are free ways to add gameplay and items to save files. Simmers have also created challenges with rules and requirements that make their gameplay more interesting. For example, the Hot Tea Legacy challenge adds layers of chaos to a playthrough.

The Hot Tea Legacy challenge is a generational challenge that has players live out their Sims' lives with specific relationship dynamics to tell a story. Many of the challenge rules feature toxic, romantic, and soap opera-level drama. Players looking to play The Sims 4 in a new way can use this guide to learn the rules of the Hot Tea Legacy challenge and discover tips and tricks for completing it.

Hot Tea Legacy Challenge Rules

The Hot Tea Legacy Challenge, created by Lxdice, allows players to experiment with wild romance storylines and attempt to complete all ten generations. Each generation must have certain Traits, Aspirations, Skills, and usually a career.

Players don't need to own all the Sims 4 packs mentioned in the rules and can change things as needed. There are also several mods or custom content suggested for completing some of the goals, but nothing is required. Players can start a new playthrough to set the traits, or they can change a pre-made Sim's traits using cheats or reward potions. To get started, players can do the following:

  • Create a founder Young Adult Sim in Create-A-Sim.
  • Customize their appearance however you want or theme it around Generation One's rules.
  • Edit the Calendar to include the following holidays:
    • Love Day
    • Flowerfest
    • Fools' Day
    • Movie Night
    • Summerfest
    • Spooky Day
    • Harvestfest
    • Winterfest
    • New Year's Eve
    • Self-Care Day

How to Edit the Calendar in The Sims 4

Players can edit the Calendar and add holidays if they own the Seasons Expansion pack. Players can add, remove, or edit holidays by opening the Calendar and using the menu bar on the side; they can also add pre-made holidays or make custom ones using icons and holiday goals.

Generation 1 (The Hopeless Romantic)

Traits

Career

Aspiration

Recommended Packs

  • Lovebug
  • Cheerful
  • Family Oriented

  • Baker

  • Romantic Explorer

  • Home Chef Hustle
  • Get to Work
  • Businesses and Hobbies
  • Seasons

Additional Rules:

  • Max out the Baking, Cooking, and Romance Skills.
  • Complete the Aspiration.
  • Sell baked goods.
  • Give the Sim's lot the Simple Living Trait.
  • Have at least three relationships and a child with each during the founder Sim's lifetime.
  • Open a bakery with Get to Work or Businesses and Hobbies.
  • Make a Family Recipe.
  • Get married to the final partner.
  • Celebrate Love Day

Generation 2 (The Other Woman)

Traits

Career

Aspiration

Recommended Packs

  • Genius
  • Outgoing
  • Romantic

  • Doctor

  • Neighborhood Confidant

  • Get to Work
  • For Rent
  • Growing Together
  • Seasons
  • Parenthood

Additional Rules:

  • Get an A in elementary school
  • Play with the Doctor's playset
  • Get an A in high school
  • Host a sleepover
  • Max the Genius, Outgoing, and Romantic Skills.
  • Befriend all coworkers
  • Have an affair with a married coworker and convince them to leave their spouse
  • Have at least two children and a Baby Shower for each
  • Host a Family Reunion, Dinner Party, or Neighborhood Potluck
  • Host two Stay Over events
  • Have the Strict Dynamic with kids
  • Celebrate Harvestfest

Generation 3 (Teen Pregnancy)

Players will need the Teen Pregnancy & Drama mod by Lumpinou to fully complete this generation. Otherwise, Sims can get pregnant as an adult, but still do everything else.

Traits

Career

Aspiration

Recommended Packs

  • Family Oriented
  • Loyal
  • Active

  • Athlete
  • Gym Owner

  • Super Parent

  • High School Years
  • Parenthood
  • Businesses and Hobbies
  • Seasons

Additional Rules:

  • Have a Teen Sim get pregnant
  • Run away with their partner
  • Make money as a Teen with part-time jobs, gigs, and scavenging
  • Max the Family Oriented, Loyal, and Active Skills
  • Complete the Aspiration
  • Join the Athlete career and quit at level seven
  • Have at least three kids (one girl required)
  • Volunteer, go on picnics, and buy gifts for the family
  • Complete the Holiday Cracker Collection
  • Celebrate Winterfest

Generation 4 (Brotherly Love)

Traits

Career

Aspiration

Recommended Packs

  • Snob
  • Self Assured
  • Materialistic

  • Nail Technician
  • Politician

  • Fabulously Wealthy

Additional Rules:​​​​​​​

  • Reach level six of the Wellness Skill as a Teen
  • Max the Charisma, Logic, and Violin Skills
  • Complete the Aspiration
  • For the first five days of Young Adulthood, work at the spa as a Nail Technician
  • Quit the Nail Technician career and join the Politician career, maxing it out
  • Date a wealthy Sim with a brother and make their family hate you
  • Marry the Sim
  • Have an affair with their brother
  • Become a B-List Celebrity
  • Hire luxury services like the Butler, Nanny, Maid, Gardener, Ranch Hand, etc.
  • Lead a prestigious social club
  • Own a Money Vault
  • Host at least two Charity Benefit events

Generation 5 (The Tragic Musician)

Traits

Additional Rules:​​​​​​​

  • Start a club as a teen and have Jam Sessions
  • Max the Piano, Guitar, and Media Production Skills
  • Create Music Tracks and Write Songs
  • Get into a relationship with a Steamy Dynamic
  • Get a tattoo dedicated to their partner
  • Get pregnant and then get married
  • Get divorced on the Teen's birthday.
  • Have the partner move out and take everything
  • Move into a trailer
  • Have the Sim form an addiction
  • Join the Entertainer career
  • Hold music lessons or classes
  • Have at least one female child
  • Celebrate New Year's Eve

Generation 6 (Body Artist)

Traits

Career

Additional Rules:​​​​​​​

  • Complete the Aspiration
  • Study Fine Arts at a University
  • Woohoo with four Sims in one night, and get pregnant
  • Drop out of University and join the Painter career or become a Tattoo Artist
  • Get a romantic partner
  • Host two Costume Parties and a Gold Spooky Party
  • Spray graffiti in public
  • Change the Sim's hair color at least three times
  • Woohoo in at least five different locations
  • Be Friends or higher with their children

Generation 7 (Man's Best Friend)

Traits

Career

Additional Rules:​​​​​​​

  • Get into a relationship as a teen with a high school sweetheart
  • Get engaged as a Young Adult
  • Join the Art Critic Career
  • Max the Gardening, Flower Arranging, and Knitting Skills
  • Complete the Aspiration
  • Host at least three Wedding Social Events
  • Woohoo with the fiancé's Best Friend the night before the wedding
  • Leave the fiancé at the altar
  • Live on an Off-the-Grid Lot
  • Own at least four different animals
  • Host the Ranch Animal Day
  • Place Solar Panels and Turbines on the Lot
  • Have at least one child
  • Complete the Decorative Egg Collection

Generation 8 (Ride or Die)

Traits

Career

Aspiration

Recommended Packs

  • Mischief

Additional Rules:

  • Begin Teen stage as a straight-A student
  • Date a "delinquent" Teen and change to an edgier style
  • Max the Mischief, Handiness, and Fitness Skills
  • Complete the Aspiration
  • Get pregnant on day one of the Young Adult stage
  • Move into a one-bedroom house
  • Reach at least level seven of the Criminal Career
  • Date another Sim in the Criminal Career
  • Have at least three Enemies
  • Make a gang using the Club System
  • Kill a Sim
  • Have a total of six children
  • Celebrate Fool's Day

Generation 9 (Curse of the Older Sibling)

Traits

Career

Aspiration

Recommended Packs

  • Family Oriented
  • Self Assured
  • Maker

  • Freelance Crafter

  • Master Maker

  • Eco Lifestyle
  • Growing Together
  • Seasons

Additional Rules:​​​​​​​

  • Have a childhood Best Friend
  • Have a childhood Enemy
  • Max the Fabrication, Cooking, and Video Gaming Skills
  • Earn money through part-time and odd jobs, hacking, writing, selling paintings, and more.
  • Get to level three of three careers as a Young Adult and then quit to freelance
  • Have the Sim's Best Friend stay over occasionally
  • Have a family outing once a week
  • Fall in love with the childhood Enemy
  • Move in the childhood Enemy
  • Have at least one child
  • Give each sibling $5,000-10,000 to move out when they become Young Adults

Generation 10 (The Glow Up)

Traits

Career

Aspiration

Recommended Packs

  • Ambitious
  • Creative
  • Self Assured

  • Actor

  • World Famous Celebrity

  • Get Famous
  • Moschino Stuff Pack

Additional Rules:

  • Max the Acting, Fitness, and Charisma Skills
  • Don't make friends as a Teen
  • Give the Sim a makeover as a Young Adult
  • Become an influencer
  • Join and max out the Acting career
  • Throw a party
  • Marry another celebrity Sim
  • Own a Sleeping Pod
  • Become a Global Superstar
  • Take family photo shoots
  • Fall for a fan or coworker
  • Get divorced
  • Celebrate Movie Night

Once players hit generation ten, they will have completed the Hot Tea Legacy Challenge in The Sims 4 . Mods such as UI Cheats and MCCC make certain aspects of the challenge easier, but players can make it their own. As long as there is drama, the tea is piping hot.

item.title: Best Hidden Gems On The Original Game Boy
item.description:
Summary

  • Kid Dracula is a clever, cute spin-off of Castlevania with unique gameplay elements.
  • Avenging Spirit stands out with its possession mechanic, tragic story, and impressive visuals.
  • Sword of Hope 2 offers a mix of RPG and point-and-click genres with a confident atmosphere.

It’s easy to think of the Game Boy as a Pokemon machine or a Tetris box, and for a lot of kids in the '90s, it probably was. But beneath all the block-dropping and Pikachu-chasing were titles that dared to be strange, clever, or just wildly ahead of their time. The kind of games that didn’t get the spotlight back then, but feel like buried treasure now. These are the ones that didn’t sell millions but absolutely deserved to.

Whether they played with genre conventions, squeezed magic out of limited hardware, or just offered something no other handheld could, these hidden gems made the most out of grayscale pixels and two buttons.

Kid Dracula

Castlevania But Make It Cute

Kid Dracula
Platformer
Shooter
Systems
Released
October 19, 1990
Developer(s)
Konami
Publisher(s)
Konami

Platform(s)
Nintendo Entertainment System
Powered by

Konami knew how to make the Game Boy sweat, and Kid Dracula is a perfect example. A spin-off of the Castlevania series in everything but tone, it takes the gothic trappings of its parent franchise and shoves them through a cartoon filter. What comes out the other end is a platformer that’s snappy, stylish, and weird in all the right ways.

Players take control of Dracula’s pint-sized son, who’s got a repertoire of spells and transformations instead of just a whip. Each stage introduces new mechanics or enemies without ever feeling like filler. And while it starts easy, the difficulty slowly creeps up with boss fights that feel surprisingly tactical. There’s even a level with a trivia minigame, because why not? Kid Dracula never got the mainstream love Metroid or Mega Man did, but anyone who found it back then knew they had something special. It’s goofy. It’s sharp. And it deserves more than being a footnote in Konami’s history.

Avenging Spirit

A Ghost, A Gun, And A Second Chance

Avenging Spirit
Platformer
Systems
Released
November 6, 1992

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E for Everyone
Developer(s)
C.P. Brain
Platform(s)
Nintendo Game Boy, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, Nintendo Switch, iOS
Powered by

Everything about Avenging Spirit feels like it came from a bizarro universe. It’s a side-scrolling shooter where the protagonist is already dead. Players start as a ghost, and the gimmick is possession; players can take over the bodies of gangsters, ninjas, robots, and even a mob boss’s pet scientist. Each body has its own weapons and playstyle, and some are vital for reaching secret paths or bonus items.

What makes it a gem is how confident it is in its weirdness. The story doesn’t pull punches either; it’s tragic from the jump, but still commits to full-on arcade action. And for a handheld title, it looks shockingly good, with big expressive sprites and smooth animation. It’s one of those rare Game Boy games that could pass for something from the Neo Geo Pocket if not for the green-tinted screen. Nobody expected Avenging Spirit to be this ambitious. That’s probably why it flew under the radar.

Sword Of Hope 2

When JRPGs Met Point-And-Click

Sword of Hope II

Released
September 4, 1992
Platform(s)
Nintendo Game Boy, 3DS
Powered by

On paper, Sword of Hope 2 sounds like a standard RPG. There’s a prince, a kingdom, and some mysterious evil threatening the land. But once it boots up, it plays more like a first-person dungeon crawler with heavy visual novel energy. It’s got that Shadowgate vibe, where players explore rooms, solve puzzles, and manage an inventory, all through a series of text-based commands and menu navigation.

What makes it so interesting isn’t just the genre fusion, but how confident it is. There’s a full save system, NPCs with branching dialogue, and item-based progression that requires actual logic rather than brute force. It’s slower than traditional RPGs, but richer in atmosphere. And while the story might start simple, it takes enough turns to keep players on their toes. Most people skipped over it back in the day, assuming it was just another RPG knockoff, but those who stuck with it found something quietly memorable.

Daedalian Opus

Tetris For People Who Like To Cry

  • Platforms : Game Boy, MSX
  • Released : April 20, 1990
  • Developer : Tokai Communications
  • Genre : Puzzle, Strategy

This one looks like a Tetris clone at first glance. Blocks fall. Players fit them into a shape. But Daedalian Opus is actually closer to pure puzzle torture. Each level gives players a shape and a specific set of tetromino-style blocks. Your job? Fit all of them into that shape perfectly. No rotation during placement. No margin for error. Just raw brain power and a lot of quiet swearing.

What’s wild is how Daedalian Opus escalates. Early puzzles are chill, even soothing. By the halfway point, it feels like trying to pack a suitcase using nothing but bricks and rage. But that’s also why it sticks. It turns Tetris into something methodical, deliberate, and maddeningly satisfying when everything finally clicks. The game has zero frills, no story, and barely any music, but it doesn’t need them. It’s one of the most quietly punishing and rewarding experiences on the entire system.

Catrap

Before Rewind Buttons, There Was This

  • Platforms : Game Boy
  • Released : June 1, 1990
  • Developer : ASK Kodansha, Kodansha
  • Genre : Puzzle, Platformer

In 1990, Catrap introduced a mechanic so far ahead of its time that people didn’t realize how brilliant it was until decades later: undoing your moves. Players control two adorable characters trapped in block-pushing puzzles filled with ladders, enemies, and one very important rule: get stuck, and you’re restarting. Unless fans hit rewind, which lets players scroll back through every action they’ve taken in the level like a VHS tape.

Aside from being ridiculously cute, Catrap is genuinely challenging. Each level ramps up in complexity, and because players swap between two characters to clear the stage together, it quickly becomes a kind of mental gymnastics. And the ability to rewind? That wasn’t just a gimmick. It gave Catrap the freedom to throw complex puzzles at the player without feeling unfair. It’s no wonder the game found a second life decades later on the 3DS Virtual Console, where people finally gave it the attention it always deserved.

Mole Mania

Miyamoto’s Other Baby Deserves More Love

Mole Mania

Released
July 21, 1996
Platform(s)
Nintendo Game Boy, 3DS
Powered by

There’s no reason Mole Mania should have been forgotten. It had Shigeru Miyamoto’s fingerprints all over it, and yet somehow ended up buried under the Game Boy’s mountain of licensed shovelware. Players control Muddy Mole, whose family has been kidnapped by a vegetable baron (yes, really). What follows is a surprisingly brainy puzzle adventure that asks players to push, pull, and dig their way through maze-like stages without softlocking themselves.

The digging mechanic is deceptively deep. Muddy can tunnel underground to bypass obstacles, but that changes the layout of the aboveground puzzle, forcing players to think in two layers at once. And unlike many early puzzle games, Mole Mania doesn’t rely on trial-and-error; it trusts the player to pay attention and learn its logic. It’s a game that feels closer to something like Zelda than anything else on the system, just with fewer swords and more cabbages.

Trip World

The Best Platformer You Never Knew You Wanted To Pet

Trip World

Released
November 27, 1992
Platform(s)
Nintendo Game Boy, 3DS
Powered by

Before Trip World became a cult collectible with absurd price tags on auction sites, it quietly released in Europe and Japan with little fanfare. Which is a shame, because Sunsoft poured more charm into this than most console platformers were managing at the time. Players take control of Yakopoo, a strange rabbit-like creature that can shapeshift mid-jump, swim, fly, and even kick enemies with its tail. And somehow, none of that ever feels overwhelming.

What makes Trip World feel special is how peaceful it can be. Unlike most platformers of the era, enemies don’t always attack on sight. Many just walk around, adding to the odd sense of tranquility. The game’s environments are lush and dreamlike, and the spritework feels almost illegal for a 1993 handheld. It’s short, for sure, but so carefully designed that it practically begs to be replayed, if not for its mechanics, then just to vibe with its world again.

item.title: Pokemon GO Ralts Spotlight Hour Guide (August 2025)
item.description:
Ralts is one of the most sought-after species in Pokemon GO, since it can evolve into Gardevoir and Gallade, depending on whether it is female or male. On that note, trainers need to look far and wide for the perfect Ralts to use them in PvP or PvE, and the Spotlight Hour is the best chance they have to catch many of these Pokemon.

With a maximum Combat Power of 609, and average stats, Ralts is not one of those Pokemon that trainers would pick for Little Cup, and when it evolves into Kirlia, things don't exactly improve. Nevertheless, its final evolutions are a different story. Gardevoir is a decent pick to counter meta Pokemon thanks to its Fairy-type, and Gallade is a powerful spammer and shield breaker. So, if players are interested in picking a decent Ralts in the next Spotlight Hour, here's all the information on the event, time, bonuses, and how to get a Shiny Ralts.

Pokemon GO: Ralts Spotlight Hour Date & Bonuses

The Ralts Spotlight Hour in Pokemon GO will begin on Tuesday, August 19, at 6 PM Local Time , and will end the same day at 7 PM Local Time. Trainers have exactly one hour to get as many Ralts as possible, looking for the ideal IV Spreads for PvP, or that valuable Hundo for PvE activities.

The bonus this time is 2x Candy for catching Pokemon , and that means players will be able to collect tons of Ralts Candy. Remember that this also doubles the amount of bonus Candy for using Pinap or Silver Pinap Berries, (though trainers shouldn't waste Silver Pinap Berries in Ralts). For those trainers looking to level up their favorite Ralts, this is a great chance to get that surplus of Candy needed to evolve and train it.

Pokemon GO: How To Get Shiny Ralts

Shiny Ralts is available in Pokemon GO, so trainers looking for a female or male Ralts can encounter a Shiny version of this cute species if they are lucky. The Spotlight Hour doesn't improve the spawn chances (unlike the Community Day events), but with so many Ralts taking over the map, trainers are bound to find one if they look hard enough.

To improve their chances, players should increase the spawning rates even higher by following these tips:

  • Use Incense near PokeStops boosted by Lure Modules to encounter more Ralts.
  • You can get better results by finding PokeStops boosted by the Windy Weather Conditions.
  • Keep walking around the PokeStop to activate the Incense effects.

Unlike other events, the Spotlight Hour doesn't host any Research Tasks that can rewards players with extra encounters with Ralts, though if players use the Party Play feature and band together, they can even exchange information about possible Hundo Spawning Locations. On that note, the Pokemon that spawn from the Incense and Daily Adventure Incense are not shared with other players, so two trainers walking side by side might encounter different Ralts lured by the effects of the Incense, and these will have different IV Spreads.
